newsitem.title: UK: BP promises to help fight climate change.
newsitem.headline: BP promises to help fight climate change.

text.p: Oil major British Petroleum Co Plc on Monday announced steps to help cut carbon dioxide emissions following growing concerns over worldwide climatic change.
BP, which has recently come under fire from environmental lobby group Greenpeace, said it wanted to take action even though there was no conclusive evidence yet of global warming.
"We must now focus on what can and what should be done, not because we can be certain climate change is happening, but because the possibility can't be ignored," BP chief executive John Browne said.

He was speaking on global warming at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California. A copy of the speech, which follows a batch of recent lobby group demonstrations in Britain against oil companies' environmental track record, was sent beforehand to Reuters in London.
Browne said BP will control its own carbon dioxide emission and take measures such as eliminate flaring of gas as much as possible.

The company, one of Britain's biggest, will also continue to support the development of solar energy, Browne said. "I'm convinced we can make solar competitive in supplying peak electricity demand within the next 10 years," he said.
BP will be commissioning a new solar manufacturing facility in California by the end of the year.
Greenpeace said BP's measures were not going far enough, adding that the company should stop looking for new oil and gas reserves.
"To continue to look for new fossil fuel reserves makes no sense when we can't afford to burn what we've already found," Greenpeace spokesman Chris Rose said in a statement.
The lobby group in April set solar panels on the roof of a BP office in Scotland in protest of oil exploration in the Atlantic Ocean west of the Shetland Islands.
